byline.contributor: Jack Ewing and Ben Protess contributed reporting.
byline.original: By BILL VLASIC and AARON M. KESSLER

abstract: Volkswagen only admitted fault in cheating on pollution tests on its diesel cars after Environmental Protection Agency threatened to withhold approval for 2016 Volkswagen and Audi diesel models; since deception became public, company has engaged in damage control, saying it will not sell 2015 and 2016 diesel cars; outcome demonstrates how environmental regulators have tools at their disposal that auto safety regulators lack.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen executives told environmental regulators repeatedly that discrepancies on pollution tests were not a deliberate attempt to deceive Washington officials.

headline.main: It Took E.P.A. Pressure to Get VW to Admit Fault
headline.print_headline: It Took E.P.A. to Pressure VW to Admit Fault

snippet: Volkswagen executives told environmental regulators repeatedly that discrepancies on pollution tests were not a deliberate attempt to deceive Washington officials.
